questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Micah 1:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone and the imagery of God's coming judgment.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the LORD' and 'judgment' in the opening verses
Pay attention to the emotional tone: from warning to lamentation (e.g., 'tell it not in Gath', 'weep not at all')
The phrase 'the mountains will melt' (v.4) is a powerful image of God's overwhelming power

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is being judged, WHAT the LORD is doing, WHERE this judgment will be felt, and WHY (the cause of judgment).
tips: Include the cities of Samaria and Jerusalem as the targets of judgment
Note the cause: the transgression of Jacob and sins of the house of Israel
The judgment will come from God's holy temple and will be visible (mountains melt)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the description of God's coming judgment (v.4), the lamentation for Samaria (v.10-11), or the call for mourning (v.10)?
tips: The image of mountains melting like wax before fire (v.4) is a vivid metaphor for God's overwhelming power
The phrase 'tell it not in Gath' (v.10) shows the depth of the coming destruction and the need for quiet, internal mourning
The comparison of lamentation to jackals (v.10) emphasizes the extreme nature of the coming suffering

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Micah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Micah warns Judah that the sins of the northern kingdom (Samaria) would bring judgment to Jerusalem
This passage shows that God's judgment is a direct response to sin and that the people must repent before it is too late
The theme of judgment is tied to the covenant relationship: Judah's failure to turn from sin leads to destruction

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reference to 'transgression of Jacob' (v.1), the meaning of 'high places' (v.2), or the concept of an incurable wound (v.5)?
tips: 'Transgression of Jacob' refers to the sin of the northern kingdom (Israel) that has affected Judah, but in the context of the prophecy, it's about the people of God
'High places' (v.2) are places of idolatry where people worship false gods, and Jerusalem is the high place of Judah
The 'incurable wound' (v.5) means the sin is so deep that it cannot be healed by human effort, but God's judgment is necessary

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: The passage describes how sin leads to judgment. What area of your life needs to be addressed with the same urgency as Micah's warning?
tips: Consider a habit or relationship that has become a 'wound' in your life that needs to be addressed
Pray for the courage to confront and change that area, just as Micah calls for lamentation and mourning
This week, identify one sin that has caused a 'wound' and take one step toward repentance

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Acknowledge the coming judgment and ask for God's mercy and protection.
tips: Thank God that He sees our sin and calls us to repentance
Ask for the strength to mourn our sins and the courage to turn away from them
Pray for the nations to hear the warning of God's judgment and turn to Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Micah 2:1-12 aloud, focusing on the contrast between the wicked's actions and God's decree.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'woe' (v.1) and the phrase 'he changes the portion of my people' (v.8)
Pay attention to the emotional tone of the oppressed (v.5-6) and the triumphant declaration of God (v.10-11)
The phrase 'the LORD at their head' (v.12) is a key image of divine leadership

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO (the oppressors in Judah) does WHAT (covets and seizes fields and houses, oppresses the poor) WHERE (in Judah) and WHY (to enrich themselves and power) in Micah 2:1-12.
tips: The oppressors are described as working evil on their beds (v.1)
The key event: coveting fields and taking them away (v.2)
The response: God's decree of disaster (v.3) and the gathering of the remnant (v.10-11)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the oppression of the poor (v.2), God's declaration of disaster (v.3), or the gathering of the remnant (v.10-11)?
tips: The phrase 'he changes the portion of my people' (v.8) is deeply personal and shows God's active role in the oppression
The image of God gathering the remnant like sheep in a fold (v.10) is a beautiful contrast to the chaos of oppression
The declaration 'the LORD at their head' (v.12) shows God's leadership in the final restoration

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Micah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Micah is warning Judah against the corruption of their society and the consequences of oppressing the poor
He emphasizes that God will deliver a time of disaster for the oppressors but will gather the remnant of Israel
This passage shows God's faithfulness to His people despite the wickedness of the oppressors

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The 'disaster' (v.3), the 'taunt song' (v.5), or the 'remnant' (v.10)?
tips: The term 'disaster' (Hebrew: 'mishpah') refers to a calamity that is not easily escaped, not a temporary setback
A 'taunt song' (v.5) is a song of mockery that the oppressed would sing to the oppressors, showing their humiliation
The 'remnant' (v.10) refers to the faithful few who will be gathered by God, not the majority

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God gathering His remnant. What can you do this week to be part of the remnant that God gathers?
tips: Identify areas where you are oppressing others (e.g., financial, emotional)
Pray for God to change your heart and become a part of the remnant
Offer to help the oppressed in your community this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray for the oppression in your life and for God's gathering of the remnant.
tips: Ask God to help you see the oppression in your life and the need for justice
Pray for the oppressed and for God to gather His remnant in your life
Thank God for His leadership as the LORD at the head of His people

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Micah 3:1-12 aloud, focusing on the vivid descriptions of corruption and the contrast with God's power.
tips: Note the repetition of 'they' and the violent imagery: tearing skin, breaking bones, eating flesh (v.3)
Pay attention to the contrast between the corrupt leaders/prophets and God's declaration of power (v.11-12)
Notice the phrase 'cry to the LORD but he will not answer' (v.4)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the leaders and prophets of Judah), WHAT they do (corrupt practices), WHERE (in Judah), and WHY (to avoid consequences of their evil deeds).
tips: Include the description of leaders eating the flesh of their people (v.3)
Note the false security of the corrupt leaders claiming the LORD is with them (v.8-10)
Mention the consequence: darkness and no vision (v.6-7)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the violent imagery of corruption (v.3), the false prophets who cry 'peace' for money (v.4), or God's declaration of power (v.11-12).
tips: The phrase 'eat the flesh of my people' (v.3) is shocking and shows extreme corruption
The false prophets who cry 'peace' but declare war (v.4) is a powerful metaphor for false comfort
God's statement: 'I am filled with power, with the Spirit of the LORD' (v.11) shows divine authority

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Micah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Micah is rebuking the corrupt religious and leadership structures in Judah
The main point is that the leaders and prophets are being punished for their injustice and false promises
This passage shows the consequence of rejecting God's justice and the need for authentic spiritual leadership

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The violent imagery, the role of false prophets, the contrast between the corrupt leaders and God's power.
tips: The phrase 'eat the flesh of my people' (v.3) is hyperbolic to emphasize the severity of corruption
'Cry Peace when they have something to eat' (v.4) refers to false prophets who promise safety for money
The concept of 'the sun shall go down on the prophets' (v.6) is a metaphor for their downfall

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of false security in leadership and how it applies to your life this week.
tips: Ask: How have I been tempted to compromise integrity for convenience or gain?
Consider a time when I've accepted false promises of security without checking the source
Practice discernment in leadership by seeking God's truth instead of human manipulation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of false prophets and the need for authentic leadership.
tips: Ask God to expose false leaders in your life and community
Pray for the courage to speak truth when it's costly
Thank God for His power to uphold justice and protect His people

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Micah 4:1-6 aloud, paying attention to the imagery of the mountain being exalted and the transformation from weapons to agricultural tools.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the mountain of the LORD' (v1, v2)
Pay attention to the contrast in v4: 'swords' and 'plowshares'
Note the shift from war to peace in the closing verses (v4-6)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the LORD and nations), WHAT (the exaltation of the mountain, the nations coming to learn God's ways, the transformation of weapons into tools of peace), WHERE (Zion, the mountain of the LORD), and WHY (the LORD's eternal rule bringing peace to all nations).
tips: Include the exaltation of the mountain of the LORD as the highest (v1)
Note the nations coming to learn God's ways (v2)
Describe the transformation of swords into plowshares (v4)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the exaltation of the mountain (v1), the transformation of swords into plowshares (v4), or the peaceful image of sitting under the vine and fig tree (v4).
tips: The mountain being the highest symbolizes God's kingdom as the center of the world
The swords becoming plowshares represents the end of war and the beginning of peace
The vine and fig tree imagery shows abundant, safe, and restful life

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Micah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Micah promises a future where God's kingdom (Zion) will be the center of peace for all nations
The passage reassures Judah that after their suffering, God will restore them and bring lasting peace
The LORD will reign forever from Zion, gathering the outcasts and establishing His rule

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The exaltation of the mountain, the transformation of weapons, or the identity of the 'lame' and 'cast off'?
tips: The 'mountain of the LORD' refers to the Temple Mount in Jerusalem (Zion), which is elevated above other mountains (v1) in this future kingdom
'Beating swords into plowshares' is a metaphor for the end of war and the beginning of peace, but it is a future promise for the entire world (v4)
The 'lame' and 'cast off' are the marginalized and outcast groups (e.g., the poor, the sick, the exiles) that God will gather and make strong (v7)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of peace in the midst of conflict: What situation requires you to be a peacemaker this week, as Micah promises the swords will be beaten into plowshares?
tips: Identify a small conflict in your relationships and pray for the peace that comes from God's rule
Practice being a peacemaker by resolving a disagreement with someone
Consider how you can help the outcast (lame or cast off) in your community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His promise of peace in the future and ask for the courage to be a peacemaker.
tips: Thank God for the mountain of the LORD (Zion) being the center of His kingdom
Pray for the strength to be a peacemaker in your relationships
Ask God to gather the outcasts (the lame and the cast off) in your life and community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Micah 5:1-5 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'Bethlehem Ephrathah' and the repeated phrase 'from ancient days'.
tips: Notice the contrast between Bethlehem's small size and its future importance
Pay attention to the phrase 'from of old, from ancient days' which emphasizes Christ's eternal origin

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the ruler) is, WHAT he will do (shepherd), WHERE he will rule (the ends of the earth), and WHY this matters (he will be peace for Israel).
tips: Bethlehem Ephrathah is the small town from which the ruler emerges
The ruler will shepherd in the strength of the LORD and be the peace of the people
He will come from ancient days, indicating his eternal nature

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the smallness of Bethlehem (v.2), the ruler coming from ancient days (v.2), or the peace he will bring (v.5)?
tips: Bethlehem being 'too little to be among the clans of Judah' is a powerful contrast to the ruler's significance
The phrase 'he shall be their peace' (v.5) is a unique promise that resolves conflict
The ruler's shepherding in the strength of the LORD (v.4) shows divine authority

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Micah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Micah was addressing Judah's current suffering and the need for a deliverer
The ruler from Bethlehem is a divine promise that the God of Israel would provide a king who would save His people
This prophecy points to Christ as the ultimate shepherd and peace for all nations

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are confusing? The small town Bethlehem? The phrase 'from of old'? The concept of peace in a war-torn land?
tips: Bethlehem Ephrathah is a small village, but the prophecy says it is the birthplace of the ruler
The phrase 'from of old, from ancient days' refers to Christ's eternal origin, not a time in the past
The peace mentioned (v.5) is not just political but a spiritual restoration

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How does the promise of the ruler from Bethlehem challenge us to be peacemakers in our communities?
tips: In your community, identify a conflict that the ruler's peace could resolve
Like the ruler who shepherds in the strength of the LORD, how can you bring peace to your neighborhood?
Pray for the Holy Spirit to give you the courage to be a peacemaker

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the ruler from Bethlehem and ask for His peace to flow through your life.
tips: Thank God that He sent Jesus, the ruler from Bethlehem, to be our peace
Pray for the strength to be a shepherd in the midst of conflict
Ask God to help you be a peacemaker in your family and community

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Take turns reading Micah 6 aloud together.
tips: Read slowly and clearly
Pause if something strikes you

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize what this passage is about.
tips: Keep it brief
Capture the main flow

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What stood out to you the most? What's the 'best bit'?
tips: Share what personally resonated
Listen to your partner

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What is the main point or central message of this passage?
tips: Think about the author's intent
Look for the big idea

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What difficulties or questions do you have about this passage?
tips: It's okay not to understand everything
Share honestly

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: What will you do about it? How will you apply this to your life?
tips: Be specific and practical
Think about this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about what you've learned and your applications.
tips: Thank God for what you learned
Pray for each other

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Micah 7:1-17 aloud, focusing on the emotional tone and repeated phrases such as 'I will look to the LORD' and 'when I fall, I shall rise'
tips: Notice the lamentation in verse 1: 'Woe is me!'
Pay attention to the repetition of 'the godly has perished' (v.2) and 'the enemy of a man are the men of his own house' (v.3)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (the people of Judah) is in trouble, WHAT (the corruption and violence) is happening, WHERE (in Judah), and WHY (the consequences of sin and idolatry)
tips: Include the state of the land: God's people have become corrupt (v.2)
Note the active violence: 'they all lie in wait for blood' (v.3) and the betrayal within families (v.3)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lamentation (v.1-2), the promise of God's compassion (v.14-17), or the phrase 'when I fall, I shall rise' (v.14)
tips: The phrase 'when I fall, I shall rise' (v.14) shows God's promise of resilience in the midst of suffering
The promise that 'the LORD will be a light to me' (v.14) is a powerful image of God's guidance in darkness
The statement 'He will tread our iniquities underfoot' (v.17) is a strong promise of forgiveness that stands out

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Micah trying to communicate to Judah through this passage?
tips: Micah is calling Judah to remember God's mercy in the midst of their suffering and corruption
He contrasts the current state of the land with God's enduring compassion and the promise of restoration
This passage serves as a reminder that God's faithfulness and love will ultimately prevail over the wicked

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The statement about the godly perishing, the promise of rising when fallen, or the betrayal within families
tips: 'The godly has perished from the earth' (v.2) refers to the spiritual corruption in Judah, not a universal end of all godly people
'When I fall, I shall rise' (v.14) is a promise of hope that the speaker is making in the midst of despair, which can be hard to grasp in the moment
'The enemy of a man are the men of his own house' (v.3) highlights the deep betrayal within the community, a cultural issue in ancient Israel

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of God's compassion and hope in the midst of suffering. What can you do this week to trust God's promise that He will help you rise when you fall?
tips: When you feel like you are in a difficult situation (fallen), pray for God's help to rise again
Ask God to 'tread your iniquities underfoot' by confessing your sins and seeking His forgiveness
Share the promise of God's light with someone who is in darkness

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for being a light in our darkness and ask for His compassion to help us rise when we fall
tips: Thank God for being a light in your darkness (v.14)
Ask God to help you trust His promise that He will tread your iniquities underfoot (v.17)
Pray for the community to experience God's compassion and for enemies to be turned away
